News and developments from Justia and the tech world -----
September 2016
 

Welcome to the September 2016 edition of 
the JUSTIA monthly client newsletter!

Learn about recent developments in online marketing, discover new features of social media, and hear about what’s going on in the JUSTIA offices.

Tech News

Lawyer Directory & Portal Traffic Statistics Now Available for Justia Premium Members

Justia Premium Members can now see how often visitors have viewed their profile and listings on the Justia and Legal Information Institute lawyer directories and legal portals. This new web traffic report tracks the number of profile impressions and page views that lawyers receive across the Justia and LII properties.
 
TECH
 

The Coming Copyright Fight Over Viral News Videos, Such As Police Shootings

In recent years, some companies have tried to buy viral videos within minutes or hours of them going viral in an attempt to license them for republication. This phenomenon raises important questions about copyright and the doctrine of fair use as applied to news media.

Google is Secretly Working on a Brand-New Operating System Called Fuschia

Google is working on a new operating system designed to run on every type of device, from desktop to mobile. Unlike the Android system, which is built on Linux, this new OS is being built from scratch.

Appeals Court: Maker of Web Spy Tool Can Be Sued for Alleged Wiretap Violations

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit recently ruled that a man could sue the maker of a computer program called WebWatcher that was allegedly used to intercept his emails and online chats with an unhappily married woman in Ohio. The lawsuit raises interesting issues of whether spy software might run afoul of state and federal wiretap laws.
 
SEO
 

Why You Should Focus on Long-Term Campaigns

Businesses should invest energy and resources not only in short-term marketing, such as PPC/advertising and social media engagement, but also in long-term marketing, including search engine optimization, original content, and communication. Long-term marketing increases quality traffic over time and helps build brand recognition and authority.

Google Lets Any Publisher Apply to Have “Critic Reviews” of Local Businesses

Google recently made changes to its local business display, allowing any publisher to request inclusion in the Critic Reviews section by using specific markup. This change is particularly notable because the Critic Reviews section is especially prominent on mobile devices, which is now how most people are searching Google.

How to Solve Duplicate Content Local SEO Issues for Multi-Location Businesses

Search Engine Land columnist Joy Hawkins offers tips on how multi-location businesses can avoid duplicate content issues. A few of these tips include: include testimonials, write out driving directions, create employee bios, and add photos.

New Google Alert Widget Saves Us From Repeatedly Googling Ourselves

If you search for your name on Google while logged into your Google account, you may notice a “Stay in the loop” widget at the bottom of the first page of search results. This feature allows you to sign up to receive a Google Alert any time your name is mentioned online.
 
Social Media
 

Facebook Business Pages Get a New Look

New navigation and a prominent call-to-action button are just a few of the changes rolled out to Facebook Pages recently. Most of the features business owners are accustomed to remain, albeit with a reorganized layout that is intended to be cleaner and more intuitive to users.

Instagram Stories Will Vanish After 24 Hours

Stories, Instagram’s new feature that lets users create slideshows of images and videos, will vanish 24 hours after each initial share. To many, this is similar to Snapchat, an app where shared images and videos have a limited lifespan. Instagram explained that its intention was to allow users to share more moments and take away some of the pressure to only publish their best photos or videos.

Reddit Will Allow Marketers to Sponsor User Posts

Soon, marketers will be able to turn organically submitted content by Redditor users into Promoted User Posts. Brands that would like to create such posts must obtain express consent from redditors in order to do so. Users who agree will be rewarded with Reddit Gold, which goes toward Reddit’s premium membership program.

Facebook Changes Its Algorithm to Avoid Clickbait

Facebook is aiming to minimize the “clickbait” content its users see on their news feeds in the future by changing its algorithm. Clickbait is content that attempts to draw attention via sensational titles or images to draw users to a particular web page. By changing its algorithm to avoid content of this nature, Facebook hopes to maintain the integrity of users’ news feeds, keep users happy, and ensure they spend more time on Facebook itself.

25 Power Words to Drive More Engagement With Your Social Campaigns

Even when you’ve built a solid audience base on social media for your business, achieving active user engagement can be a challenge. Choosing the right words for your social campaigns can make all the difference in this instance, as well as encourage a higher level of engagement. Particularly worth noting is that these words can differ from one social media platform to another.

Up to 10 Photos, Videos Can Now Be Included in Facebook Carousel Ads

Carousel ads were once limited to five images or videos, but Facebook has recently doubled this minimum allowance. Advertisers can now include up to 10 images and videos in their carousel ad campaigns.
 
Legal industry
 

Law Professor: ABA Discrimination Code Tramples on Lawyer Speech

The American Bar Association recently adopted a new professional misconduct rule that has drawn criticism from a number of legal ethics experts. Ronald Rotunda, a law professor at Chapman University, Fowler School of Law, argues that the new rule presents constitutional problems and constitutes a misguided “foray into political correctness.”

The Voodoo and How-To of Lawyers’ Duty to Search the Internet

Google is playing an increasingly important role in legal proceedings. In some jurisdictions, lawyers have an affirmative duty to use the Internet as part of efforts to exercise due diligence in attempting to locate parties and some other procedural aspects of cases. In another case, a judge found the dangers of researching potential jurors on the Internet outweighed any potential benefit in that case and therefore asked both parties to the lawsuit to agree not to search the Internet for information on the jurors.
